raw_text:
PlayStation 3 processor unveiled
 
 The Cell processor, which will drive Sony's PlayStation 3, will run 10-times faster than current PC chips, its designers have said.
 
 Sony, IBM and Toshiba, who have been working on the Cell processor for three years, unveiled the chip on Monday. It is being designed for use in graphics workstations, the new PlayStation console, and has been described as a supercomputer on a chip. The chip will run at speeds of greater than 4 GHz, the firms said. By comparison, rival chip maker Intel's fastest processor runs at 3.8 GHz. Details of the chip were released at the International Solid State Circuits Conference in San Francisco. The new processor is set to ignite a fresh battle between Intel and the Cell consortium over which processor sits at the centre of digital products. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006, while Toshiba plans to incorporate it into high-end televisions next year. IBM has said it will sell a workstation with the chip starting later this year.
 
 Cell is comprised of several computing engines, or cores. A core based on IBM's Power architecture controls eight "synergistic" processing centres. In all, they can simultaneously carry out 10 instruction sequences, compared with two for current Intel chips.
 
 Later this year, Intel and Advanced Micro Devices plan to release their own "multicore" chips, which also increase the number of instructions that can be executed at once. The Cell's specifications suggest the PlayStation 3 will offer a significant boost in graphics capabilities but analysts cautioned that not all the features in a product announcement will find their way into systems. "Any new technology like this has two components," said Steve Kleynhans, an analyst with Meta Group. He said: "It has the vision of what it could be because you need the big vision to sell it. "Then there's the reality of how it's really going to be used, which generally is several levels down the chain from there."
 
 While the PlayStation 3 is likely to be the first mass-market product to use Cell, the chip's designers have said the flexible architecture means that it would be useful for a wide range of applications, from servers to mobile phones. Initial devices are unlikely to be any smaller than a games console, however, because the first version of the Cell will run hot enough to need a cooling fan. And while marketing speak describes the chip as a "supercomputer" - it remains significantly slower than the slowest computer on the list of the world's top 500 supercomputers. IBM said Cell was "OS neutral" and would support multiple operating systems simultaneously but designers would not confirm if Microsoft's Windows was among those tested with the chip. If Cell is to challenge Intel's range of chips in the marketplace, it will need to find itself inside PCs, which predominantly run using Windows.
llama3.2:1b: The PlayStation 3 processor features a 10-times faster Cell processor compared to current PC chips, running at speeds above 4 GHz and with 8 cores controlling "synergistic" processing centers. The chip is expected in 2006 for the PS3, and Toshiba plans to incorporate it into high-end televisions next year.
llama3.2:3b: Sony, IBM and Toshiba unveiled the Cell processor, a supercomputer on a chip, running 10 times faster than current PC chips. The chip will drive Sony's PlayStation 3 and has been described as a game-changer for graphics workstations and digital products. It features multiple cores that can carry out 10 instruction sequences at once, and is expected to ignite a battle between Intel and the Cell consortium.
gemma2:2b: The Cell processor, designed for the PlayStation 3 and other high-performance applications, boasts a tenfold increase in processing speed compared to current PC chips. This new chip, based on IBM's Power architecture, will allow for simultaneous execution of 10 instruction sequences, compared to two for Intel's best processors. The Cell's flexible architecture promises applications beyond gaming consoles like servers and mobile phones. However, its initial release is expected in the form of high-end devices due to processing heat requirements. While the chip is "OS neutral," Microsoft Windows compatibility remains uncertain. To challenge Intel's market dominance, Cell needs wider adoption within PCs which predominantly use Windows.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Sony has revealed a new processor named "Cell" for its PlayStation 3 console that will be faster and more powerful than current PC processors. The design aims to provide an improved gaming experience and a better user interface, with the ability to run a wide range of applications including servers and mobile phones. Cell is comprised of several computing engines, or cores, which can simultaneously carry out 10 instruction sequences compared with two for current Intel chips.

While the PlayStation 3 is likely to be the first mass-market product to use Cell, Sony's designers have said that the flexible architecture allows it to be useful in a wide range of applications. The cell design has the vision and potential to power future PC systems as well, but marketing will need to confirm if Microsoft's Windows operating system will also be included with Cell.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Sony unveiled the PlayStation 3 processor based on IBM and Toshiba's Cell design, capable of running 10 times faster than PC chips and designed for graphics workstations, consoles, and as a supercomputer-on-a-chip in televisions. It will be used in 2006 as part of Sony's PlayStation 3 console and later incorporated into high-end televisions by Toshiba.
qwen2.5:3b: The Cell processor for PlayStation 3 will operate at speeds over 4 GHz, ten times faster than current PC processors, according to Sony, IBM, and Toshiba. This chip is designed for graphics workstations and the new PlayStation console, dubbed a supercomputer on a chip. Intel's fastest processor operates at 3.8 GHz. The Cell has eight synergistic processing cores based on IBM’s Power architecture, capable of executing up to ten instructions simultaneously compared to two in current Intel chips. Analysts expect it to offer significant graphics improvements but caution about the level of features that will be implemented. While initially targeting gaming devices like PlayStation 3 and high-end TVs next year, Toshiba plans to incorporate Cell into mobile phones within a year. IBM has already released a workstation with this chip starting later in the year. Despite being described as a supercomputer, Cell still lags behind top-performing supercomputers.
opencoder:1.5b: The Cell processor, which aims to revolutionize gaming consoles, may well compete with current PC processors in terms of speed and efficiency. It is designed for high-performance computing environments, with a focus on gaming. It features a larger number of cores and processing units, enabling it to handle more complex tasks at once. The new PlayStation 3, released next month, might soon offer significant advancements in graphics capabilities and power management. Despite the upcoming announcement of the processor, it is not yet available for purchase.
smollm:1.7b:
The PlayStation 3 processor unveiled has several key features that set it apart from other gaming consoles and computers:

1. **10-times faster than current PC chips**: The Cell processor is designed to be significantly faster than current processors used in gaming consoles and high-end computers, which will enable smoother performance and more efficient use of system resources.
2. **Power consumption**: The Cell processor is expected to consume less power than current processors, making it suitable for mobile devices and other battery-powered applications.
3. **Flexible architecture**: The Cell processor's flexible architecture allows it to be used in a wide range of applications beyond gaming consoles and high-end computers, such as servers and mobile phones.
4. **Supercomputer capabilities**: The Cell processor is designed to support multiple operating systems simultaneously, which could enable it to run more demanding tasks than current processors.
5. **Sales start in 2006 for the PlayStation 3**: The PlayStation 3 console will be launched in 2006, with a launch date of 2007 for the first version. This means that the Cell processor will need to find its way into gaming consoles and other devices before it can become widely available.

The key details of the PlayStation 3 processor unveiled include:

1. **Cells**: The PlayStation 3 will use a combination of PowerPC and IBM's Power architecture, which is based on the Power ISA standard. This allows for better performance and compatibility with existing power-efficient systems.
2. **Synergistic cores**: The Cell processor will have eight synergistic cores, each capable of executing multiple instructions simultaneously. This increases the overall processing capacity of the chip compared to traditional processors.
3. **Higher clock speed**: The Cell processor is expected to run at higher clock speeds than current processors used in gaming consoles and high-end computers, which could enable it to handle more demanding tasks.
4. **Cooling system**: The PlayStation 3 will likely feature a cooling system to keep the chip running smoothly during intense gaming sessions or when running multiple applications simultaneously.
5. **Integration with other components**: The Cell processor will need to be integrated with other components, such as graphics processing units (GPUs), random access memory (RAM), and storage devices, to enable it to run games and other demanding tasks efficiently.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the PlayStation 3 processor and its developments. Let me read through it carefully first.

The article starts by talking about Sony revealing a new Cell processor that's 10 times faster than current PC chips. That sounds pretty groundbreaking because I know some older processors are already quite fast. The designers have been working on this for three years, combining cells from IBM and Toshiba. It mentions how the chip is designed for graphics workstations, the PlayStation, and described as a supercomputer.

Comparing it to Intel's processor at 3.8 GHz, which is less powerful than Apple's APU or NVIDIA's T2000, this Cell processor seems like a significant leap in computing power. The upcoming release of the PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006, and Toshiba plans to include it in their high-end TVs next year. IBM has confirmed they'll sell workstations with the chip later this year.

The article also talks about how the Cell processor uses cores based on IBM's Power architecture, which can handle more instruction sequences simultaneously. There are plans for other companies like Intel and Advanced Micro Devices to release similar "multicore" chips later. The analysts caution that while the vision is good, not all features will translate into real systems yet.

The conclusion mentions that the PlayStation 3 might be the first mass-market product using the Cell processor, but it's still a slow enough computer to run on fans and won't compete with current PCs, which mostly use Windows. IBM said it's OS-neutral, meaning it should support multiple operating systems, but Microsoft's Windows testing isn't confirmed yet.

So, I need to condense this into a summary that captures the key points: the Cell processor is 10 times faster, designed for graphics workstations and PS3, described as a supercomputer, compared to Intel's specs. The PlayStation 3 is expected in 2006 with IBM plans for TVs next year. Analysts note potential future competition but caution about real-world performance.
</think>

The PlayStation 3 processor introduces a revolutionary Cell chip that runs 10 times faster than current chips. Designed for graphics workstations and PlayStation, it features multiple cores based on IBM's Power architecture, capable of handling more instruction sequences simultaneously compared to Intel's 3.8 GHz processor. The release is expected in 2006, with IBM plans to include it in TVs next year. Analysts caution that while the vision is promising, real-world performance may lag behind current PCs and Microsoft's Windows testing remains pending. The Cell processor, with its flexibility and potential applications across various devices, could challenge Intel in the marketplace, though success will require adapting inside PCs.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Cell processor, which aims to drive Sony's PlayStation 3 console, has been described as a supercomputer on a chip and will unveil the new technology in the worksatition for high-end televisions next year. The newly announced processor boasts a flexible architecture that allows it to run at a top speed of greater than 4 GHz, a factor that sets it apart from rival chip designs currently running at around 3.8 GHz. Sony's Cell processor is set to ignite a new battle with Intel and the Cell consortium over which processor will sit in digital products. The PlayStation 3, slated for release in 2006, will be the first mass-market product to use the chip, with initial devices possibly requiring a cooling fan to keep them at optimal temperatures. As the new technology remains significantly slower than the slowest computer on the list of world's top 500 supercomputers, Sony has not yet confirmed whether Windows will be among those supported by Cell. The Cell processor has also been tested with Microsoft's operating system and has yet to confirm whether it can challenge Intel's dominance in the marketplace.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The Cell processor, developed by IBM and Toshiba in collaboration with Sony, has been unveiled as a powerful performance booster for PlayStation 3. This cutting-edge chip runs significantly faster than current high-end PC processors. Its designers say the Cell will be suitable for use in graphics workstations and is set to ignite a fierce battle between Intel and the Cell consortium over which processor sits at the center of digital products. 

The PlayStation 3, due out next year, is expected to include a new chip designed by the Cell consortium. It's believed to be superior and exciting innovation for gamers and enthusiasts alike. The developers behind the Cell processor say they aimed to create a supercomputer-class processor that could process ten times more instructions in real-time than current PC chips. The new chip is expected to offer significant performance gains compared to other existing digital products, including Toshiba's high-end television workstations.

IBM plans to release its own multicore chip - a subset of the Cell processor - later this year for use in personal computers. These multicore chips can handle multiple tasks simultaneously and potentially increase computing power by a factor of ten. In comparison, rival chip maker Intel's fastest processor runs at 3.8 GHz. The new processor is expected to ignite a fierce battle between Intel and the Cell consortium over which processor sits at the center of digital products.

As for its potential impact on the marketplace, the Cell processor could revolutionize performance in digital devices like PlayStation 3. By running significantly faster than current PC chips, the new chip could enhance gaming experiences and make powerful games available to a wider audience. It's likely that initial products using the Cell processor will be large and expensive, but the potential for widespread market adoption remains exciting.
phi:2.7b: Sony has unveiled a new processor called Cell that will drive their PlayStation 3 console and will be faster than current PC chips by running at 10-times faster speeds than Intel's fastest processor. The Cell processor is being designed for use in graphics workstations and high-end televisions, with a speed of greater than 4 GHz compared to Intel's 3.8 GHz. IBM, Toshiba, and Sony have been working on the chip for three years, which has been described as a supercomputer on a chip. While Cell may not be as fast as other top 500 supercomputers, it is more flexible in terms of being able to run multiple operating systems simultaneously. The first product to use Cell will likely be PlayStation 3 consoles but its benefits could also extend to servers and mobile phones. Despite the hype surrounding Cell, analysts are cautious about how many features will actually make their way into products due to the need for a vision for selling it, followed by the reality of practical applications.
orca-mini:3b: PlayStation 3 processor unveiled as a supercomputer on a chip, running 10 times faster than current PC chips with 8 core control based on IBM's Power architecture, able to simultaneously execute 10 instruction sequences, compared with two for current Intel chips. Cell consortium consists of several computing engines or cores, flexible architecture making it useful for a wide range of applications, from servers to mobile phones. Initial devices unlikely to be any smaller than a games console, but first version of the Cell will run hot enough to need a cooling fan. Unclear if Microsoft's Windows is among those supported, designers confirm that Cell is "OS neutral" and supports multiple operating systems simultaneously.
